awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Kinematics and Chemistry of M33- Determining the Past, Present and Future of the M31/M33 system
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will use the Keck telescope to study individual stars in M33, a companion galaxy to the Andromeda galaxy (M31). Using spectroscopy, they will obtain information about the motion and star formation history of the disk and potential halo of M33. They will use this information to learn if its interactions with M31 have influenced its evolution. The science program is integrated with a high school research program that will introduce students to cutting-edge research on M33's formation history.

With a mass ten times lower than M31's and a star formation rate 10 times higher, M33 is the best local analog for high z galaxies. Spectroscopic observations of resolved stars in M31 will provide measurements of the line-of-sight stellar velocities and dispersion and quantitative comparisons of the dynamics of the stellar and gas disk components. It will also produce the first iron and alpha-element abundance distributions for stars in M33. Finally, it will definitively determine of M33 has a stellar halo. This chemo-dynamical analysis will provide critical observational constraints on internal and external heating mechanisms affecting low-mass stellar disks. It will also constrain models of M33's orbit around M31, yielding insights into whether M33 is on first infall or has interacted substantially with M31 in the past.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The vast majority of stars in the Universe reside in the disks of galaxies. Yet galaxy disks are under frequent threat from collisions with smaller galaxies. The survival of the disks of small, low-mass galaxies is challenging to understand, since additional, internal phenomena can send stars careening out of the disks and into the galaxy's halo. Spectroscopy of individual stars throughout a galaxy's disk enables us to decipher the evolution of the disk over time.

Triangulum (M33), a satellite of the Andromeda (M31) galaxy, is the only ``dwarf Spiral'' galaxy that is close enough to our galaxy, the Milky Way, to study its individual stars in detail. Triangulum has a mass that is ten times smaller than Andromeda’s and is forming stars at a rate 10 times higher, making Triangulum the best local example of the smaller, still-growing galaxies that were common early in the history of the Universe. 

We studied Triangulum using the DEIMOS multi-object spectrograph on the Keck 2 telescope located on Mauna Kea in Hawaii. We wish to recognize and acknowledge the very significant cultural role and reverence that the summit of Mauna Kea has always had within the indigenous Hawaiian community. We are most fortunate to have the opportunity to conduct observations from this mountain.

We obtained spectra of individual stars in Triangulum. When a star's light is spread out into a spectrum, we can measure the speed at which the star is moving towards us (the ``line-of-sight velocity") and the amounts of different elements in the star. Stars in a stellar disk move in an orderly fashion, following each other around the center of the galaxy in a thin plane, while stars in a stellar halo follow their own individual orbits.  This leads to very different distributions of line-of-sight velocities for stars in a disk and halo. In larger galaxies, the formation of disks and halos are quite different, with stars in the disk formed within the galaxy itself, and stars in the halo mostly deposited there by smaller galaxies that collided with the larger galaxy and were torn apart.  Whether small galaxies like Triangulum have stellar halos, and how they were formed, remain open questions.

This program measured the line-of-sight velocities of more than 5,000 stars in Triangulum.  We developed statistical models to measure the distributions of the stars' velocities.  We discovered that Triangulum has a significant number of stars in a stellar halo. Surprisingly, we found stars of all ages (young, intermediate age, and old) in Triangulum's stellar halo, indicating at least some of the halo stars were born in Triangulum's disk and later kicked out into its halo.

This program also measured the amounts of different elements in stars belonging to Triangulum's disk and halo. We were interested in measuring the ratio of lighter elements, like calcium, magnesium, silicon, and titanium, collectively called alpha (α) elements, to the heavier iron (Fe). When this ratio (α/Fe) is measured and compared against the amount of iron for a population of stars, it tells you how fast, or efficiently, stars were formed.  Stars formed in different environments (e.g., the disk of Triangulum vs. galaxies smaller than Triangulum) will have different abundances of alpha elements relative to iron.

We made the first measurements of the abundances of these elements for stars in Triangulum.  We found that while the majority of Triangulum's halo stars appear similar in elemental abundance to the stars in the disk, there is also a more iron-poor and alpha-rich population in the stellar halo.  This indicates a mixed halo population, with some halo stars being born in Triangulum's disk and later kicked into the halo, and others deposited by one or more smaller galaxies that crashed into and merged with Triangulum.

Simulations of low-mass disks predict a variety of ways that stars can be kicked out of a galaxy's disk and into its halo. Before our program, there were few observations that could provide insight into the importance of these different mechanisms. We compared our measurements with simulated galaxies of similar size and appearance to Triangulum.  The simulated galaxies had stellar halos that were mostly formed of stars born in and kicked out of the galaxies' disks.  Our measurements provide the first opportunity to compare the detailed properties of a low-mass disk galaxy to predictions of how galaxy disks evolve over time.

This project trained junior researchers at all levels.  Postdoctoral, graduate, and undergraduate student researchers were responsible for many of the above results. We mentored high school and college students, including from groups under-represented in STEM, who conducted original research, asking questions whose answers were not known.  Several of these students presented their results at professional astronomical meetings. We introduced students and teachers from around the world to the process of collecting astronomical data by hosting virtual Shadow the Scientist sessions while we operated telescopes.
